All three vaccines authorized in the U.S. ‚Äî made by Johnson & Johnson, Moderna, and Pfizer and BioNTech ‚Äî greatly reduce the risk of getting Covid-19.
They also have a high efficacy against more serious outcomes like hospitalization and death.

See more: https://t.co/N1it9ZKnQW

The FDA set a goal for Covid-19 vaccines trials of an efficacy rate of at least 50% and a confidence interval lower bound of no lower than 30%. Here are efficacy confidence intervals from major coronavirus vaccine trials. https://t.co/N1it9ZKnQW https://t.co/yWtdaiLS0l

The efficacy percentage, called a point estimate, isn‚Äôt a precise number because trials only look at a limited number of people. Scientists measure the uncertainty around that number with a so-called confidence interval, which can be large or small. https://t.co/N1it9ZKnQW

Efficacy percentages can change when scientists look at different outcomes. Johnson & Johnson‚Äôs vaccine had an 85% efficacy rate against severe cases of Covid-19 worldwide. That means the vaccine will prevent a lot of hospitalizations and deaths. https://t.co/N1it9ZKnQW https://t.co/C9rjgNjFbJ
A 0% efficacy means that vaccinated people are at as much risk as people who got the placebo; 100% means that the risk was entirely eliminated by the vaccine. https://t.co/N1it9ZKnQW

Scientists count those in a clinical trial who contracted Covid-19 and divide them into two groups: those who got a placebo, and those who got the vaccine. In the Johnson & Johnson trial, the difference in the risk faced by those two groups ‚Äî the efficacy ‚Äî was 72%. https://t.co/JuYIWBSxQW

What should you know about vaccine efficacy?
